results.title: Treaty – Yothu Yindi
results.credit_line: ℗ 1991 Yothu Yindi (Yunupingu / Kellaway / Williams / Yunupingu / Mu)
results.brief_description: Montage is commonly used in music videos, yet in Yothu Yindi’s ‘Treaty’ (1991) it helped communicate the musicians’ disdain for “all those talking politicians” as footage of then Prime Minister Bob Hawke at the presentation of the Barunga Statement intersected with the powerful lyrics.
results.description: Montage is a common tool used in many music videos, yet in the case of Yothu Yindi’s song Treaty (1991) it helped communicate the musicians disdain for “all those talking politicians” as footage of then Prime Minister Bob Hawke at the presentation of the Barunga Statement intersected with the powerful lyrics. The spliced images became a political statement, with director Stephen Johnson making sure the micro-documentary was put it in a form where audiences who didn’t watch the news would see it.
description_for_label: Montage is a common tool used in many music videos, yet in the case of Yothu Yindi’s song Treaty (1991) it helped communicate the musicians disdain for “all those talking politicians” as footage of then Prime Minister Bob Hawke at the presentation of the Barunga Statement intersected with the powerful lyrics. The spliced images became a political statement, with director Stephen Johnson making sure the micro-documentary was put it in a form where audiences who didn’t watch the news would see it.
results.credit_line_for_label: ℗ 1991 Yothu Yindi (Yunupingu / Kellaway / Williams / Yunupingu / Mu)

results.title: Leaps and Bounds – Paul Kelly and the Coloured Girls
results.brief_description: A love letter to Melbourne – where Paul Kelly lived during the late 70s – the music video for Leaps and Bounds (1987) shows sweeping views across the city’s skyline and much-loved landmarks like the MCG.

constellations_primary.name: Raising the Roof: on-screen levity on rooftop
constellations_primary.description: Performances soar to new heights on the rooftop, not only showcasing skylines but also creating electrifying drama, comedy and spectacle.

results.title_for_label: Leaps and Bounds – Paul Kelly and the Coloured Girls
results.description: A love letter to Melbourne – where Paul Kelly lived during the late 70s – the music video for ‘Leaps and Bounds’ (1987) shows sweeping views across the city’s skyline and much-loved landmarks like the MCG, which is also namechecked in the song’s opening line. Directed by Mike Bell, Kelly and band were filmed playing on top of the Punt Road silos for the clip which is beloved for its time capsule quality.
description_for_label: A love letter to Melbourne – where Paul Kelly lived during the late 70s – the music video for ‘Leaps and Bounds’ (1987) shows sweeping views across the city’s skyline and much-loved landmarks like the MCG, which is also namechecked in the song’s opening line. Directed by Mike Bell, Kelly and band were filmed playing on top of the Punt Road silos for the clip which is beloved for its time capsule quality.

results.title: My People – The Presets
results.brief_description: The breakout single for Sydney dance duo The Presets, ‘My People’ (2007) was one of the biggest hits of that year, propelled by the music video from director Kris Moyes’s use of sci-fi aesthetics in the clip.

constellations_primary.name: My People
constellations_primary.description: The breakout single for Sydney dance duo The Presets, 'My People' was one of the biggest hits of 2007 and propelled by the engaging music video.

results.description: The breakout single for Sydney dance duo The Presets,’ My People’ was one of the biggest hits of that year and propelled by the music video from director Kris Moyes. The sci-fi aesthetic of the clip and their sound directly influenced The Black Eyed Peas track ‘Boom Boom Pow’ after frontman will.i.am became a fan while exposed to The Presets music during the filming of in X-Men Origins: Wolverine in Sydney, Australia.
description_for_label: The breakout single for Sydney dance duo The Presets,’ My People’ was one of the biggest hits of that year and propelled by the music video from director Kris Moyes. The sci-fi aesthetic of the clip and their sound directly influenced The Black Eyed Peas track ‘Boom Boom Pow’ after frontman will.i.am became a fan while exposed to The Presets music during the filming of in X-Men Origins: Wolverine in Sydney, Australia.

results.title: Elevator Operator – Courtney Barnett
results.brief_description: Courtney Barnett’s ‘Elevator Operator’ (2016) leans hard into theatrical inspirations like the work of Wes Anderson and features familiar screen faces like Madgda Szubanski, Sleater-Kinney, Tim Rogers, Paul Kelly and Michael Leunig as they travel through the elevator in Melbourne’s Nicholas Building.

constellations_primary.name: Elevator Operator: Up and down, the on-screen gift of elevators
constellations_primary.description: Inspired by Courtney Barnett playing an elevator operator in her hit song of the same name, we look at how they're used on-screen for comedy, drama and suspense, with the small, confined boxes forcing characters to physically confront each other.

results.description: The music video as a mini movie is an enduring concept within the genre, first achieving mainstream popularity with Michael Jackson’s Thriller (1983). This idea was toyed with in Courtney Barnett’s Elevator Operator(2016), which leans hard into theatrical inspirations like the work of Wes Anderson and features familiar screen faces like Madgda Szubanski, Sleater-Kinney, Tim Rogers, Paul Kelly and Michael Leunig as they travel through the elevator in Melbourne’s Nicholas Building.
description_for_label: The music video as a mini movie is an enduring concept within the genre, first achieving mainstream popularity with Michael Jackson’s Thriller (1983). This idea was toyed with in Courtney Barnett’s Elevator Operator(2016), which leans hard into theatrical inspirations like the work of Wes Anderson and features familiar screen faces like Madgda Szubanski, Sleater-Kinney, Tim Rogers, Paul Kelly and Michael Leunig as they travel through the elevator in Melbourne’s Nicholas Building.

results.title: Wild Stallion Mountain – The Bombay Royale
results.brief_description: Melbourne band The Bombay Royale make “vintage Bollywood-inspired surf, spy, disco and funk” and their video for Wild Stallion Mountain (2015) clearly reflects that, playing like a mash-up of Bollywood, 60s psychedelia, kitsch, exploitation cinema and classic Hollywood Westerns.

constellations_primary.name: Wild Stallion Mountain: Genre Mash-ups
constellations_primary.description: The Bombay Royale are known for combining funk, disco and pop with the sounds of classical Indian music together with the soundtracks of Bollywood cinema. Their music videos similarly hybridise  genres and styles to create intoxicating visual mash-ups.

results.description: Wearing their influences firmly on their sleeve, Melbourne band The Bombay Royale make “vintage Bollywood-inspired surf, spy, disco and funk” and their video for ‘Wild Stallion Mountain’ (2015) clearly reflects that. With both their sound and style linked very closely to movies, the music clip plays like a visual mash-up of their various inspirations including Bollywood, 60s psychedelia, the kitsch, exploitation cinema and classic Hollywood Westerns.
description_for_label: Wearing their influences firmly on their sleeve, Melbourne band The Bombay Royale make “vintage Bollywood-inspired surf, spy, disco and funk” and their video for ‘Wild Stallion Mountain’ (2015) clearly reflects that. With both their sound and style linked very closely to movies, the music clip plays like a visual mash-up of their various inspirations including Bollywood, 60s psychedelia, the kitsch, exploitation cinema and classic Hollywood Westerns.

results.title: Go Bang – PNAU
results.brief_description: Australian dance act PNAU are celebrated for groundbreaking visuals in their live act and music videos, including for their single Go Bang (2017) which featured Kira Divine. The clip creates a psychedelic, cosmic journey through animation, the glow-in-the-dark effects and an aquatic aesthetic.

constellations_primary.name: Go Bang
constellations_primary.description: Australian dance act PNAU are renowned for groundbreaking visuals in their music videos, including for their 2017 single 'Go Bang' which featured Kira Divine.

results.description: Australian dance act PNAU are celebrated for groundbreaking visuals in their live act and music videos, including for their single ‘Go Bang’, which featured Kira Divine. Setting out to create a psychedelic, cosmic journey through the use of animation, the glow-in-the-dark effects and aquatic aesthetic conjure images of James Cameron’s Avatar and the introduction of singing crab Tamatoa in Disney’s Moana.
description_for_label: Australian dance act PNAU are celebrated for groundbreaking visuals in their live act and music videos, including for their single ‘Go Bang’, which featured Kira Divine. Setting out to create a psychedelic, cosmic journey through the use of animation, the glow-in-the-dark effects and aquatic aesthetic conjure images of James Cameron’s Avatar and the introduction of singing crab Tamatoa in Disney’s Moana.

results.title: Somebody I Used To Know – Gotye ft. Kimbra
results.brief_description: One of the first music videos to go viral in the age of the internet, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ (2011) by Gotye (and featuring Kimbra) has been viewed over 1.3 billion times on YouTube.
results.title_for_label: Somebody I Used To Know – Gotye ft. Kimbra
results.description: One of the first music videos to go viral in the age of the internet, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ by Gotye (and featuring Kimbra) has been viewed over 1.3 billion times on YouTube. The use of body paint and early animation technique stop motion helped drive the track to a No.1 hit in the US and Australia, as well as countless comedic parodies and rip-offs in the intervening years.
description_for_label: One of the first music videos to go viral in the age of the internet, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ by Gotye (and featuring Kimbra) has been viewed over 1.3 billion times on YouTube. The use of body paint and early animation technique stop motion helped drive the track to a No.1 hit in the US and Australia, as well as countless comedic parodies and rip-offs in the intervening years.

results.title: Great Southern Land – Icehouse
results.brief_description: Although it looks like it was shot in Central Australia, Icehouse’s music video for ‘Great Southern Land’ was actually filmed in a disused quarry in Sydney. A second music video was made for the song to tie-in with its use in Young Einstein.

constellations_primary.name: Great southern land?
constellations_primary.description: Australia is often mythologised in film and TV, but national myths must not only be embraced, but resisted.

results.description: Although it looks like it was shot in the heart of Central Australia, Icehouse’s music video for their most popular track – ‘Great Southern Land’ – was actually filmed in a disused quarry in the Sydney suburb of Wahroonga. Solarised clips and shots of a campfire at night help capture the sense of isolation in the lyrics. A second music video was made for the song several years later to tie-in with its use in Young Einstein (1988).
description_for_label: Although it looks like it was shot in the heart of Central Australia, Icehouse’s music video for their most popular track – ‘Great Southern Land’ – was actually filmed in a disused quarry in the Sydney suburb of Wahroonga. Solarised clips and shots of a campfire at night help capture the sense of isolation in the lyrics. A second music video was made for the song several years later to tie-in with its use in Young Einstein (1988).

results.title: Dream a Little Crazy – Architecture in Helsinki
results.brief_description: Renowned for their colourful and crazy videos, Architecture in Helsinki’s clip for Dream A Little Crazy (2013) is no exception. A collaboration between body architect Lucy McRae and designer Rachel Wingfield, the music video presents a “biological bakery” as it creates an edible anatomy.

constellations_primary.name: Dream A Little Crazy: The next stage of human evolution
constellations_primary.description: Collaborators Lucy McRae and Rachel Wingfield created a ‘biological bakery’ for Architecture In Helsinki’s "Dream A Little Crazy". Manufacturing a series of mass-produced band members the clip explores speculative science and the future of the human body’s evolution.

results.title_for_label: Dream a Little Crazy – Architecture in Helsinki
results.description: Renowned for their colourful and crazy videos, Architecture in Helsinki’s clip for ‘Dream A Little Crazy’ was no exception. A collaboration between body architect Lucy McRae and designer Rachel Wingfield, the music video presents a “biological bakery” as it creates an edible anatomy. The Melbourne alt-pop darlings pointed to properties such as The Rocky Horror Picture Show (1975), Weird Science (1985) and Frankenstein as influences for the concept.
description_for_label: Renowned for their colourful and crazy videos, Architecture in Helsinki’s clip for ‘Dream A Little Crazy’ was no exception. A collaboration between body architect Lucy McRae and designer Rachel Wingfield, the music video presents a “biological bakery” as it creates an edible anatomy. The Melbourne alt-pop darlings pointed to properties such as The Rocky Horror Picture Show (1975), Weird Science (1985) and Frankenstein as influences for the concept.
